lom:description.lom:string: MichSeis encompasses three activities: education, earthquake monitoring, and research. Students at all levels can be involved in all three activities. MichSeis seismographic stations produce seismograms, that can be used by a large number of people for a variety of uses. Virtually all of the computer activity can be done on a Macintosh, the key program is SeismoView. This program reads computer files that contain seismograms. You can display the seismogram, zoom the amplitude and time axes, and produce various graphic and text output. The files are produced by a Macintosh-based seismographic station, using the program SeismoGraf. There are several accessory programs and HyperCard stacks that may be useful. For example, the KSCM people produced a stack that shows seismograms of the Kobe, Japan earthquake, and the "SeismoLog" stack allows any user to calculate the surface wave magnitude of an earthquake.

"MichSeis is the concept that a network of independent, yet cooperative, digital seismographic stations can be operated by schools and institutions throughout Michigan*." (*or anywhere else in the world!) *Any earthquakes today? *Where are the most recent earthquakes? *Seismo-Cam, What is the ground doing right now in Ann Arbor? *Data: seismograms for EQ location and magnitude of regional events *EduPhase *QuakeView *Data: Seismograms and graphics for earthquakes and other events *MichSeis Newsletters *Information on Stations and people *How to find epicentral distance
